comment.author: 42283697@N08
comment._content:
This was the link line that connected Corks mainline station(Kent) with the long gone terminus of the West Cork Railway at Albert Quay.
St Patricks church in the background.
PS. Note the bell in the drivers hand.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: I notice the Esso gas station in the background...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/chartrouse] Tom, that's fantastic! Hadn't spotted the bell...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/chartrouse] That's exactly what it is. That's the cross city railway which connected the GS&WR station on Glanmire Road (Kent) with the Cork Bandon & South Coast Railway station (Albert Quay). It ran on regular city roads and remained in use to move freight between the stations until the mid-1970s - when the new freight station opened at North Esk. Here's a few other pics of large locos crossing cork with other road traffic. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] That petrol station was open right up to the early 2000s. When it was replaced by the (decidedly underwhelming) "Unity House".....

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] How excellent! Thanks for the other pics - crazy to see a dirty big goods train alongside ickle Ford Cortinas and VW Beetles...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 60812213@N04
comment._content:
The engine is about to enter Clyde Cutting, a curved passage for rail only, between two buildings owned by the Clyde Shipping Co.
 The line was built as an independent connection between the West Cork line and the GSWR Cork main line by the Cork City Railway Co. Opened on 01/01/1912 for goods. 
A man with a red flag had to walk ahead of every train.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abandonedrailsireland] Here's a photo of one of those flag men that was contributed above by guliolopez... And got a great haul of new tags from your comment, so thanks again!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 60812213@N04
comment._content: Paying passenger trains only ever operated for the summer of 1914. What a year to start a service for tourists!

comment.author: 77753804@N08
comment._content: The cobblestones around the railway line were lethal in wet weather.  It was easy to skid and get a motorbike wheel neatly into the railway tracks.  Not too easy to get the tyre back out as it was a snug fit.  I know I wasn't the only one to come off my motorbike with a wheel stuck in the tracks in heavy rain.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
